change.subject: Section 3A: Information relating to an identifiable living individual

change.summary: This section defines when information is considered to be relating to an identifiable living individual, distinguishing between direct and indirect identification.

pillars.pillar: This change provides a clearer definition of when information is considered to be relating to an identifiable living individual, which can help protect individuals' right to privacy.

change.subject: Section 3A: Information relating to an identifiable living individual
change.quote: “(5) For the purposes of this section, an individual is identifiable by a person “by reasonable means” if the individual is identifiable by the person by any means that the person is reasonably likely to use. change.summary: This section further clarifies the criteria for determining whether an individual is identifiable by a person "by reasonable means". It takes into account factors such as time, effort, costs, and available technology and resources.

pillars.pillar: This change provides additional guidance on how to determine whether an individual is identifiable, which can help protect individuals' right to privacy.

change.subject: Section 4: Consent to law enforcement processing

change.subject: Section 5: Lawfulness of processing

change.summary: This section adds a new lawful basis for processing personal data, stating that processing is lawful if it is necessary for the purposes of a recognised legitimate interest.

change.subject: Section 5: Lawfulness of processing
change.quote: “9. change.summary: This section provides examples of types of processing that may be considered necessary for the purposes of a legitimate interest, including direct marketing, intra-group transmission of personal data for internal administrative purposes, and processing for the purposes of ensuring the security of network and information systems.

change.subject: Section 6: The purpose limitation

change.summary: This section clarifies that processing of personal data is not lawful solely because it is compatible with the purposes for which the data was collected.

change.subject: Section 8A: Purpose limitation: further processing
change.quote: “3. change.subject: subsection 84B
change.quote: Additional requirements when processing for RAS purposes 1. Paragraph 2 does not apply— (a) to the collection of personal data (whether from the data subject or otherwise), or (b) to cases in which the RAS purposes cannot be fulfilled by further processing in the manner described in that paragraph. 4. For the purposes of paragraph 2, processing permits the identification of a living individual only in cases described in section 3A(2) and (3) of the 2018 Act (information relating to an identifiable living individual).
change.summary: A new section titled "Additional requirements when processing for RAS purposes" is inserted, which outlines the requirements for processing personal data for research, archiving, and statistical purposes, including the need for appropriate safeguards and the prohibition of identification of living individuals.

pillars.pillar: This change establishes specific requirements for the processing of personal data for research, archiving, and statistical purposes, ensuring the protection of individuals' rights and freedoms.

change.subject: subsection 84C
change.quote: Appropriate safeguards 1. This Article makes provision about when the requirement under Article 84B(1) for processing of personal data to be carried out subject to appropriate safeguards is satisfied. 2. The requirement is not satisfied if the processing is likely to cause substantial damage or substantial distress to a data subject to whom the personal data relates. 3. The requirement is not satisfied if the processing is carried out for the purposes of measures or decisions with respect to a particular data subject to whom the personal data relates, except where the purposes for which the processing is carried out include the purposes of approved medical research. 4. The requirement is only satisfied if the safeguards include technical and organisational measures for the purpose of ensuring respect for the principle of data minimisation (see Article 5(1)(c)), such as, for example, pseudonymisation. 5. In this Article— “approved medical research” means medical research carried out by a person who has approval to carry out that research from— (a) a research ethics committee recognised or established by the Health Research Authority under Chapter 2 of Part 3 of the Care Act 2014, or (b) a body appointed by any of the following for the purpose of assessing the ethics of research involving individuals— (i) the Secretary of State, the Scottish Ministers, the Welsh Ministers or a Northern Ireland department; (ii) a relevant NHS body; (iii) United Kingdom Research and Innovation or a body that is a Research Council for the purposes of the Science and Technology Act 1965; (iv) an institution that is a research institution for the purposes of Chapter 4A of Part 7 of the Income Tax (Earnings and Pensions) Act 2003 (see section 457 of that Act); “relevant NHS body” means— (a) an NHS trust or NHS foundation trust in England, (b) an NHS trust or Local Health Board in Wales, (c) a Health Board or Special Health Board constituted under section 2 of the National Health Service (Scotland) Act 1978, (d) the Common Services Agency for the Scottish Health Service, or (e) any of the health and social care bodies in Northern Ireland falling within paragraphs (b) to (e) of section 1(5) of the Health and Social Care (Reform) Act (Northern Ireland) 2009 (c. 1 (N.I.)).

pillars.pillar: The provision for powers to make regulations requiring the provision of customer data could potentially affect legal processes by setting requirements and procedures for the access and provision of such data.

change.subject: Section 35
change.summary: This section grants the Secretary of State or the Treasury the power to make regulations that enable or require data holders to produce, collect, retain, or make changes to customer data, including rectification of inaccurate data, at the request of a customer or authorized person.

pillars.pillar: This change could potentially affect small businesses and micro businesses, as well as innovation in the supply or provision of goods, services, and digital content affected by the regulations.
The change may have an impact on competition in markets for goods, services, and digital content affected by the regulations or other markets.

change.subject: Section 63
change.quote: The regulations may make provision about requests relating to customer data, including provision about the circumstances in which a data holder may or must refuse to act on a request.
change.summary: This section allows the regulations to include provisions regarding requests for customer data, including circumstances in which a data holder may or must refuse to act on a request.

pillars.pillar: The regulations may have an impact on data holders and the effects for existing and future customers.

change.subject: Section 64
change.quote: The Secretary of State or the Treasury may by regulations make provision requiring a data holder to publish business data or to provide business data on request— (a) to a customer of the trader, or (b) to another person of a specified description (a “third party recipient”).
change.summary: This section grants the Secretary of State or the Treasury the power to make regulations that require a data holder to publish or provide business data to customers or other specified persons upon request.

pillars.pillar: The change may have effects for existing and future customers, data holders, small businesses, micro businesses, and innovation in the supply or provision of goods, services, and digital content affected by the regulations.
The change may have an impact on competition in markets for goods, services, and digital content affected by the regulations or other markets.

change.subject: Section 66
change.quote: This section is about the provision about decision-makers that regulations under section 62 or 64 must or may (among other things) contain.
change.summary: This section addresses the provision about decision-makers that must or may be included in regulations under section 62 or 64.

pillars.pillar: The provision about decision-makers may have an impact on the resolution of disputes and appeals to a court or tribunal.

change.subject: Section 67
change.quote: The Secretary of State or the Treasury may by regulations make provision for the enforcement of data regulations, and for the enforcement of requirements imposed in exercise of a power conferred by regulations under this Part, including provision for enforcement by a specified public body (an “enforcer”).
change.summary: This section grants the Secretary of State or the Treasury the power to make regulations for the enforcement of data regulations and requirements imposed by regulations under this Part, including enforcement by a specified public body.

pillars.pillar: The provision about enforcement may have an impact on the enforcement of data regulations and requirements.

change.subject: Section 69
change.quote: This section is about provision that regulations under this Part conferring power on an enforcer to impose a financial penalty may or must (among other things) contain.
change.summary: This section addresses the provision that regulations under this Part must or may contain when conferring power on an enforcer to impose a financial penalty.

pillars.pillar: The provision about financial penalties may have an impact on the enforcement of data regulations and the rights of persons affected by the exercise of an enforcer's functions.

change.subject: Section 70
change.quote: The Secretary of State or the Treasury may by regulations make provision enabling a person listed in subsection (2), or a person acting on their behalf, to require other persons to pay fees for the purpose of meeting expenses incurred, or to be incurred, in performing duties, or exercising powers, imposed or conferred by regulations under this Part, and make provision about how amounts paid as fees must or may be used.
change.summary: This section grants the Secretary of State or the Treasury the power to make regulations that enable certain persons to require other persons to pay fees for the purpose of meeting expenses incurred in performing duties or exercising powers imposed or conferred by regulations under this Part.

pillars.pillar: The provision about fees may have an impact on the expenses incurred by persons performing duties or exercising powers under the regulations.

change.subject: Regulations under subsection (1)
change.quote: Regulations under subsection (1) enabling a person to determine the amount of a fee must require the person to publish information about the amount and how it is determined.
change.summary: Regulations under subsection (1) must require the person to publish information about the amount and how it is determined.

pillars.pillar: The change ensures transparency in the determination of fees, which could have an impact on businesses and individuals who are subject to these fees.

change.subject: Regulations under subsection (1)
change.quote: Regulations under subsection (1) may (among other things) make provision about— (a) interest on any unpaid amounts; (b) the recovery of unpaid amounts.

pillars.pillar: The change provides regulations for the interest on unpaid amounts and the recovery of unpaid amounts, which could have an impact on businesses and individuals who owe these amounts.

change.subject: Regulations under subsection (1)
change.quote: Regulations under subsection (1) may only provide for a levy in respect of expenses of decision-makers or enforcers to be imposed on data holders that appear to the Secretary of State or the Treasury to be capable of being directly affected by the exercise of some or all of the functions conferred on the decision-makers or enforcers by regulations under this Part.

pillars.pillar: The change allows for the imposition of a levy on data holders that are directly affected by the functions of decision-makers or enforcers, which could have an impact on businesses and individuals who are data holders.

change.subject: Regulations under subsection (1)
change.quote: Regulations under subsection (1) providing for a specified public body to impose a levy must— (a) make provision about how the rate of the levy is to be determined; (b) make provision about how the period in respect of which the levy is payable is to be determined; (c) require the body to publish information about the rate, the period and how they are determined.
change.summary: Regulations under subsection (1) must make provision about the determination of the rate and period of the levy imposed by a specified public body, and require the body to publish information about the rate, the period, and how they are determined.

change.subject: Regulations under subsection (1)

change.subject: 85 Duty to notify the Commissioner of unlawful direct marketing
change.quote: “26A Duty to notify Commissioner of unlawful direct marketing (1) A provider of a public electronic communications service must notify the Commissioner of any reasonable grounds the provider has for suspecting that a person is contravening or has contravened any of the direct marketing regulations in the course of using the service. (2) A provider of a public electronic communications network must notify the Commissioner of any reasonable grounds the provider has for suspecting that a person is contravening or has contravened any of the direct marketing regulations in the course of using the network or using a public electronic communication service provided by means of the network. (3) A notification under this regulation must be given within the period of 28 days beginning with the day on which the reasonable grounds for suspicion come to the attention of the provider. (4) “Direct marketing regulations” means regulations 19 to 22. 26B Fixed penalty for failure to comply with regulation 26A (1) If a provider of a public electronic communications service or public electronic communications network fails to comply with regulation 26A, the Commissioner may issue a fixed monetary penalty notice in respect of the failure. (2) The amount of a fixed monetary penalty under this regulation shall be £1,000. (3) Before serving a fixed monetary penalty notice, the Commissioner must serve the provider with a notice of intent. (4) The notice of intent must— (a) state the name and address of the provider; (b) state the nature of the failure; (c) state the amount of the fixed monetary penalty; (d) include a statement informing the provider of the opportunity to discharge liability for the fixed monetary penalty; (e) indicate the date on which the Commissioner proposes to serve the fixed monetary penalty notice; and (f) inform the provider that the provider may make written representations in relation to the proposal to serve a fixed monetary penalty notice within the period of 21 days beginning with the day the notice of intent is served. (5) A provider may discharge liability for the fixed monetary penalty if the provider pays to the Commissioner the amount of £800 within the period of 21 days beginning with the day the notice of intent is served. (6) The Commissioner may not serve a fixed monetary penalty notice until the period within which representations may be made has expired. (7) The fixed monetary penalty notice must state— (a) the name and address of the provider; (b) details of the notice of intent served on the provider; (c) whether there have been any written representations; (d) details of any early payment discounts; (e) the grounds on which the Commissioner imposes the fixed monetary penalty; (f) the date by which the fixed monetary penalty is to be paid; and (g) details of, including the time limit for, the provider’s right of appeal against the imposition of the fixed monetary penalty.
change.summary: Providers of public electronic communications services and networks must notify the Commissioner of any reasonable grounds for suspecting direct marketing violations. The Commissioner may issue a fixed monetary penalty for non-compliance, and providers have the opportunity to discharge liability by paying a reduced amount within a specified period.

pillars.pillar: The insertion establishes a duty for providers of public electronic communications services and networks to notify the Commissioner of direct marketing violations, which helps protect privacy rights.

change.subject: section 250A
change.summary: This change allows for the creation of information standards related to information technology (IT) and IT services, including provisions for design, quality, contracts, functionality, connectivity, interoperability, portability, storage, access, and security.

pillars.pillar: This change provides a framework for regulating and standardizing information technology and IT services, ensuring their quality, security, and interoperability.
This change promotes the development and use of standardized and secure information technology and IT services.

change.subject: section 251ZB
change.quote: “251ZB Notice requesting compliance by relevant IT providers (1) If the Secretary of State has reasonable grounds to suspect that a relevant IT provider is not complying with an information standard which applies to the provider, the Secretary of State may give the provider a written notice which— (a) identifies the standard in question, (b) sets out the Secretary of State’s grounds for suspecting that the provider is not complying with the standard, (c) asks the provider to comply with the standard within a period specified in the notice, (d) asks the provider, within a period specified in the notice, to provide evidence to the Secretary of State’s satisfaction that the provider is complying with the standard, and (e) if the Secretary of State considers it appropriate, sets out the steps that the Secretary of State considers the provider must take, within a period specified in the notice, in order to comply with the standard. (2) A period specified for the purposes of subsection (1)(c), (d) or (e) must be a period of at least 28 days beginning with the day on which the notice is given. (3) The Secretary of State may, by giving the relevant IT provider a further written notice, vary or revoke a notice given under subsection (1). 251ZC Public censure of relevant IT providers (1) If the Secretary of State has reasonable grounds to suspect that a relevant IT provider is not complying with an information standard which applies to the provider, the Secretary of State may publish a statement to that effect. (2) The statement may include the text of a notice given to the provider under section 251ZB. (3) Before publishing a statement under this section, the Secretary of State must give the relevant IT provider— (a) a copy of the terms of the proposed statement, and (b) an opportunity to make representations about the decision to publish a statement and the terms of the statement. (4) If, after considering any representations, the Secretary of State decides to publish the statement, the Secretary of State must inform the relevant IT provider before publishing it.
change.summary: This change empowers the Secretary of State to issue notices to relevant IT providers suspected of non-compliance with information standards, request compliance within a specified period, and take necessary steps to ensure compliance. It also allows the Secretary of State to publicly censure non-compliant providers by publishing a statement.

pillars.pillar: This change strengthens the enforcement of information standards for IT providers, ensuring compliance and accountability.
This change promotes the adherence to information standards in the development and provision of IT services.
